title: Expect mixed case props not to throw development warnings if they evaluate to `undefined`
body:
**Bug report** **What is the current behavior?** When running in development mode, basic DOM elements report (correctly) when they see mixed case props, which aren't supported. If a component puts a mixed-case prop with a value of `undefined` on a DOM element, it still throws a warning. (But `undefined` values don't seem to be passed, generally). ```js const GoodComponent = () =>
Should not warn
; ``` ...produces... > Warning: React does not recognize the `hullaBalloo` prop on a DOM element. If you intentionally want it to appear in the DOM as a custom attribute, spell it as lowercase `hullaballoo` instead. If you accidentally passed it from a parent component, remove it from the DOM element. Demo: https://codepen.io/pixelbandito/pen/mYWWby?editors=1111 **What is the expected behavior?** 1. If a component puts a mixed-case prop with a value of `undefined` on a DOM element, it doesn't throw a warning.` values don't seem to be passed down anyway). ```js const GoodComponent = () =>
Should not warn
; ``` 2. If a component puts a mixed-case prop with a value on a DOM element, throw a warning. ```js const BadComponent = () =>
Should warn
; ``` The expected behavior would help me write terse wrappers that pass props down to their children. In my actual use case, I have a `inNewTab` prop that uses [prop-types](https://www.npmjs.com/package/prop-types) to set a default of undefined. I'd like to pass props down to children in most cases without worrying about whether the `children` prop will be a component or a bare DOM element. **Which versions of React, and which browser / OS are affected by this issue? Did this work in previous versions of React?** I tested with React 16.8.6, because that was the current version listed in npm
